text.p: Following are the main stories in Croatian newspapers on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Demilitarisation of Eastern Slavonia, Croatia's last Serb-held enclave will involve only heavy artillery and will include only neighbouring Serbia with Hungary acting as a witness, government sources say.
- Leading oil company INA receives its first $150 million long-term international loan.
- Bank Austria opened subsidiary in Zagreb.
- Prime Minister Zlatko Matesa to sign bilateral free-trade and social security agreement with Macedonia.
- Will our drivers be banned from using mobile telephones and smoking following the examples of Italy and Poland?

- Central bank says kuna stability will not be threatened when it replaces the Yugoslav dinar in Eastern Slavonia this month as the amount in use will only be a fraction of the monetary mass used in Croatia.
- Police arrest Nikola Smolcic who masterminded a 45 million kuna fraud operation in Zagreb's central payments buro.
- Ministry of tourism has chosen a new graphic symbol ahead of the summer season which contains elements of the Croatian coat of arms.
- International wine fair opens in Zagreb gathering over 380 participants from 12 European countries.

- "I belong to none of the factions", says liberal mayor of Osijek Zlatko Kramaric in an interview, referring to looming rift within the liberal party led by the president Vlado Gotovac and Drazen Budisa.
- Workers of Uljanik shipyard in the northern port of Pula stage strike demanding payment of their salaries for March. -- Zagreb Newsroom, 385 1 4557075
